Title: Design an innovative waste recycling trash bin based on the requirements from customers (Binusian) in Bina Nusantara University
Source title: IOP Conference Series: Earth and Environmental Science
Affiliations: Industrial Engineering Department, Faculty of Engineering, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Herawan, S.G., Industrial Engineering Department, Faculty of Engineering, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Bagaskara, A., Industrial Engineering Department, Faculty of Engineering, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia
Abstract: The problem regarding waste recycling is still difficult to do, especially in an environment where the level of public awareness is still less concerned with the importance of cleanliness. At Bina Nusantara University there are organic and nonorganic trash bins, but the function is still not optimal due to the unfavorable interest of Binusian to use it or to carry out recycling activities. The survey was conducted using a questionnaire to 114 Binusian respondents qualitatively to get responses from 14 attributes related to recycling care and the design of the trash. The response from these 14 attributes will be the customer voice that is processed using Quality Function Deployment (QFD) to determine technical priorities that can be used to meet customer requirements. From the planning matrix, the factors that must be improved are the availability of organic and nonorganic waste bins, as well as improvements to the design of existing trash bins at Bina Nusantara University. Implementation of technical requirements in the form of rewards for recycling activities carried out especially for plastic waste, making redesigns for unique and innovative bins with 70% stainless steel and 30% fiberglass, and making a system that is integrated with accounts for rewarding is expected to be able meets 14 customer requirement attributes. © 2020 Published under licence by IOP Publishing Ltd.
Author Keywords: innovative bins; Quality Function Deployment (QFD); questionnaire; waste recycling
Index Keywords: Quality function deployment; Recycling; Sales; Surveys; Customer requirements; Plastic wastes; Public awareness; Quality function deployments (QFD); questionnaire; Technical requirement; Waste bins; Waste recycling; Bins

Authors: Kasih T.P., Purwondho R., Danil D., Radjagukguk R., Bagaskara A.
Title: Germination enhancement of green bell pepper (Capsicum annuum L) by using non thermal argon plasma
Source title: IOP Conference Series: Earth and Environmental Science
Affiliations: Professional Engineer Program Department, Faculty of Engineering, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Industrial Engineering Department, Faculty of Engineering, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Kasih, T.P., Professional Engineer Program Department, Faculty of Engineering, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Purwondho, R., Professional Engineer Program Department, Faculty of Engineering, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Danil, D., Professional Engineer Program Department, Faculty of Engineering, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Radjagukguk, R., Industrial Engineering Department, Faculty of Engineering, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Bagaskara, A., Industrial Engineering Department, Faculty of Engineering, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia
Abstract: An attempt to enhance the germination of green bell pepper has been tried by using dry processing non thermal (cold) argon plasma treatment. As an emerging non thermal technology, cold plasma could be used to give a pretreatment to a thermal-sensitive material, such as pretreatment to seeds of bell pepper prior to be planted in soil to understand the effect of this dry process during the germination period. In this experiment, the used argon plasma was generated by flowing argon gas with the rate of 2 L/min through a positively charged of stainless pipe at a distance of 15 mm from aluminum plate electrode. With an applied voltage of 9.8 kV (peak-to-peak) electrical energy from a high voltage AC power supply, argon plasma irradiation was employed to the bell pepper seeds for a predetermined period of time as pretreatment to the seeds during pre-planting. It was found that the temperature of the plasma never exceeded 35°C during the plasma irradiation to assure that no thermal damage occurred to the seeds. It was also confirmed from this study that by giving non thermal plasma treatment for 30 minutes to the seeds may enhance the germination of the bell pepper plants up to 90% in stem length and almost 2.5 times in root length compared to the pepper without treatment. © 2020 Published under licence by IOP Publishing Ltd.
Author Keywords: agriculture; green bell pepper; Non-thermal plasma; seed germination
Index Keywords: Agriculture; Argon; Bells; Cultivation; Electric power systems; Irradiation; Plasma applications; Shotcreting; Argon plasma treatment; Bell peppers; Non-thermal plasma treatment; Non-thermal technology; Nonthermal plasma; Plasma irradiations; Seed germination; Thermal sensitive material; Seed
